selected_quotes: Gas evolution in #supercapacitors with deep eutectic electrolyte studied in situ

citation.abstract: One of the primary causes of ageing in supercapacitors are the irreversible faradaic reactions occurring near the operating voltage limit which lead to the production of gases resulting in device swelling, increased resistance (ESR), and lowering of the capacitance. In this study, we report a investigation of a protic "Deep Eutectic Solvent" (DES) consisting on mixture of Lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide salt (LiFSI) with formamide (FMD) as H-bond donor (xLiFSI = 0.25 ; C = 2.5 M LiFSI) as electrolyte for AC based EDLC. Physical characterization of viscosity, conductivity and ionicity of electrolyte in wide range of temperatures indicate above 88% salt dissociation. The in-situ pressure measurements are focused on understanding the effect of cycling conditions on the rate of gas generation quantified by the in-operando pressure variation (dP/dt). These measurements demonstrate that about 25% of the faradaic reactions leading to gas generation are electrochemically reversible. Finally, the cell ageing studies demonstrate a promising potential of LiFSI/FMD as a protic electrolyte for AC based EDLCs and higher energy density close to 30 Wh.kg-1 at 2.4 V.

publisher_subjects.name: Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, Particle And Plasma Physics

citation.title: Gas evolution in activated carbon based supercapacitors using protic deep eutectic solvent as electrolyte
